title: 111_hr1315
content: The "Terrorist Detainees Procedures Act of 2009" prohibits the detention of unlawful enemy combatants at Naval Station, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba by December 31, 2009. Status reviews are required for individuals detained at Guantanamo Bay. The "Terrorist Detainees Procedures Act of 2009" mandates status reviews by a panel of military judges for individuals suspected of being unlawful enemy combatants detained at Guantanamo Bay. The panel has exclusive jurisdiction to determine the detainee's status following procedures similar to those of an investigation under section 832 of title 10, United States Code. The "Terrorist Detainees Procedures Act of 2009" requires status reviews by military judges for detainees at Guantanamo Bay. A detainee is entitled to an interpreter with appropriate security clearance. Military judges must be commissioned officers with legal qualifications. Each detainee must receive a status review within 120 days, extendable for good cause. The Detainee Treatment Act of 2005 is repealed. The Detainee Treatment Act of 2005 is amended to remove sections 1005 and 1405. Reviews conducted under section 1005 before the enactment of this Act do not meet the new requirements. The Detainee Treatment Act of 2005 is amended to remove sections 1005 and 1405. Reviews conducted under section 1005 before the enactment of this Act do not meet the new requirements. SEC. 4. DISPOSITION OF DETAINEES AFTER STATUS REVIEWS. Any person determined to be an unlawful enemy combatant shall be transferred to a detention facility in the US, charged with a violation of law, and tried in a military court or district court. They may also be transferred to an international tribunal or a NATO-run facility. Any unlawful enemy combatant can be transferred to a NATO-run detention facility or another country with assurances against torture, or held according to the law of armed conflict until hostilities cease or they are no longer a threat. Charges may be brought against them in a military or district court. Any person found not to be an unlawful enemy combatant after a review under section 3 can be transferred to their country of citizenship, place of capture, or a different country with assurances against torture, or released. The transfer of a person under subsection (a) shall not be considered an entry into the United States for purposes of immigration status. SEC. 5. Habeas Corpus for Detainees at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Repeals prohibition on habeas corpus for detainees at Guantanamo Bay. Jurisdiction limited to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Sense of Congress to suspend judicial review of pending applications until completion of status reviews required under section 3. SEC. 6. Repeal of Military Commissions Act of 2006. Title 10, United States Code, is amended by repealing chapter 47A and making conforming amendments throughout the code. This includes striking references to chapter 47A in various sections and tables. Title 10, United States Code, is amended by repealing chapter 47A and making conforming amendments throughout the code, including striking references to chapter 47A in various sections and tables. Subsection (b) is amended by removing the exception related to military commissions established under chapter 47A. The President must submit a report to Congress within 120 days of this Act's enactment, outlining recommendations for statutory changes needed to establish a comprehensive Federal policy for handling individuals captured in armed conflicts and counterterrorism operations. In this Act, the term "unlawful enemy combatant" is defined as a person who has engaged in hostilities against the United States or its co-belligerents. The term "co-belligerent" refers to any State or armed force directly engaged with the United States in hostilities. The term "lawful enemy combatant" includes members of regular forces of a State party engaged in hostilities against the United States. In the context of defining enemy combatants, a lawful combatant can be a member of a militia, volunteer corps, or organized resistance movement under responsible command, wearing a recognizable sign, openly carrying arms, and following the law of war. Additionally, a lawful combatant can also be a member of a regular armed force professing allegiance to a government engaged in hostilities not recognized by the United States. The amendments made by this Act will be effective upon enactment and will apply to all cases related to the detention, transfer, treatment, trial, or conditions of detention of aliens held by the United States since September 11, 2001.
